title: How to Boil an Octopus

steps.headline: Thaw your frozen octopus and beat it on the counter.
steps.description: It is believed that freezing an octopus helps to break up the tough muscle fibers. So, purchase a frozen one and let it defrost in your fridge overnight. If you have a fresh octopus, you can replicate the effects of freezing by it by hitting the octopus on a solid countertop or sink approximately 10 times. Some chefs maintain that hitting a thawed octopus on the counter should still be done, so try it out if desired.

steps.headline: Mix in 3 US tbsp (44 mL) of granulated salt per 1 US qt (950 mL) of water.
steps.description: Combine the ingredients in a large pot. This 5% solution is used to brine the octopus and helps dissolve more of the muscle fibers.

steps.headline: Let the octopus brine for about 3 hours.
steps.description: Put the octopus in the pot and ensure it’s covered completely. If you are short for time, you can brine for a shorter period of time. However, you will likely get slightly more fibrous texture in the meat.

steps.headline: Heat a pot of water and sherry vinegar at 190 to 200 °F (88 to 93 °C).
steps.description: Add 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of sherry vinegar to each 1 US qt (950 mL) of water. Make sure to use enough water to cover all of the octopus. Heat the mixture to a low simmer. Some Greeks swear by using a copper pot, although there is no real evidence behind this idea. The sherry vinegar helps to break down tough tissue. If you don’t have sherry, you can use balsamic vinegar instead. You can use a meat thermometer to test the water as it heats.

steps.headline: Cook the octopus for 1 hour per 1 lb (0.45 kg) of meat.
steps.description: So, if you have 4 lb (1.8 kg) of meat to cook, expect it to take 4 hours for the meat to soften. You can check the meat periodically by piercing the upper portion (towards the part that connects to the head) with a knife to see if it’s tender.

steps.headline: Remove the octopus from the water and serve it immediately.
steps.description: Carefully drain the boiling water from the pot first, then remove the octopus from the pot. Cut the legs into smaller chunks, if desired, or serve it as-is.

steps.headline: Defrost the octopus and hit it on the counter 10 times.
steps.description: Frozen octopus comes pre-cleaned, so all you have to do is let it thaw. Stick it in the fridge for 8-12 hours to let it defrost gradually. Then, beat the octopus on a countertop or sink 10 times to tenderize the meat before you begin cooking. If you’re working with a previously frozen octopus, this step is optional. However, some cooks swear by it, regardless.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 200 °F (93 °C).
steps.description: Set aside a deep, dry pan and a piece of foil that you can cover the octopus with. Let the oven heat while you work through the next blanching steps. Once you remove the octopus from heat in the next step, you will want to be ready to insert it directly into the oven.

steps.headline: Blanch the meat for 30 seconds in boiling water.
steps.description: In a pot large enough to submerge the octopus into, heat water to a boil. Add 1  tsp (4.9 mL) of salt to the water. Then, use tongs to set the octopus meat down into the water for just 30 seconds. Be sure the water is up to a rolling boil before blanching the meat. If the water isn’t quite at the full temperature, you run the risk of the heat not dissolving the tissue as intended. Using tongs or a pair of spoons to let the octopus down into the pot avoids splashing boiling water. Use a pair of oven mitts as well, just in case!

steps.headline: Put the octopus in the pan and cover it loosely with foil.
steps.description: The heat of the oven will create enough moisture in the pan to keep the meat from sticking, so just place the octopus directly in the pan. Make sure the pan has sides of at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) to contain the liquid. Cover it loosely with a piece of tin foil to keep it from browning too much.

steps.headline: Bake the octopus for 1 hour per 1 lb (0.45 kg).
steps.description: Octopus meat is 80% water, so baking it is going to release some of that liquid into the pan. Therefore, when removing the pan, be careful not to spill the hot liquid out. For instance, cook a 3 lb (1.4 kg) octopus for 3 hours.

steps.headline: Set aside the meat to cool while you boil the liquid from the pan.
steps.description: Carefully pour the liquid from the pan into a pot. Bring it to a boil and cook it until it becomes slightly gelatin-like. The amount of time it will take to concentrate the liquid depends on how much of it you have.

steps.headline: Cover the octopus with the liquid.
steps.description: Since the liquid has no added water, it is essentially a concentrated brine of the octopus’s own flavoring. You can now serve the octopus in whatever dish you are preparing!
